clinical_study.brief_title: Expression of CXCL5 in Urinary Bladder Urothelial Carcinoma
clinical_study.official_title: Immunohistochemical Expression of CXCL5 as a Valuable Prognostic Marker in Urinary Bladder Urothelial Carcinoma

brief_summary.textblock: Bladder carcinoma is the 9th most prevalent cancer worldwide and the 13th most common cause of cancer-related deaths. Approximately three quarters of all cases are diagnosed in men. Lack of understanding of mechanisms that govern bladder carcinoma metastasis and recurrence is a major reason for its high mortality rates. CXCL5 is a small (8-14 kDa) protein that is a member of the CXC chemokine family. It is an inflammatory and angiogenic chemokine that binds to its cell-surface receptor CXCR2 to execute its roles in angiogenesis, immune response, tumor progression and invasion by activating the PI3K/AKT pathway-induced up regulation of matrix metalloproteinase. Numerous reports have indicated that CXCL5 plays vital roles in cancer progression in various neoplasms; abnormal expression of CXCL5 has been identified in many tumors. Increased expression of CXCL5 is associated with advanced tumor stages, local invasion, metastatic potential and cancer-related inflammation, which is involved in many aspects of malignancy in cancer biology. Recent studies have revealed that CXCL5 could serve as a potential prognostic biomarker for patients with bladder carcinoma.

detailed_description.textblock:
Bladder carcinoma is the 9th most prevalent cancer worldwide and the 13th most common cause of cancer-related deaths. Approximately three quarters of all cases are diagnosed in men; it constitutes the 5th most common cancer in men. There are different histological variants of bladder carcinomas which show different phenotypic, biological and prognostic impacts. The most common histological type of bladder carcinoma is urothelial carcinoma (UC) which constitutes about 90% of all bladder cancers. Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC), adenocarcinoma and other rare types represent the remaining 10%. Cigarette smoking is the most important risk factor for UC, followed by environmental pollution, occupational exposure to carcinogens, urinary tract infections, chronic inflammations and irradiations .
Bladder carcinoma is divided into three diagnostically different categories; non-muscle invasive, muscle invasive and metastatic bladder carcinoma. Bladder carcinoma mortality is mainly determined by the initial tumor stage and success of treatment, reflected by progression rates of high risk non-muscle invasive UC and cure rates of muscle-invasive UC. Clinicopathological parameters play a major role in determining the therapeutic strategies for UC, but are usually not reliable predictors of prognosis. Therefore, studying novel biomarkers that have a potential value as prognostic markers and serve as new therapeutic targets is required .
In Egypt, bladder carcinoma is considered the third most common cancer in both sexes representing 6.9% of total malignancies with the highest mortality rates worldwide. Infection by S. haematopium and Cigarette smoking are the most important risk factors of bladder carcinoma in Egypt. Due to efforts to eradicate S. haematopium and treat infected patients in the past three decades, there is decrease in the incidence of SCC. However, the incidence of UC rising from 16% to 65.8%, becoming at present the most common tumor type due to increased exposure to etiological factors as smoking, pesticides and other causative agents.
Lack of understanding of mechanisms that govern bladder carcinoma metastasis and recurrence is a major reason for its high mortality rates. Matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs) play irreplaceable roles in migration and invasion, which are mediated by many signal pathways including MAPK/P38 signaling, PI3K/AKT signaling and Wnt/Frizzled signaling accompanied by epithelial to mesenchymal transition (EMT), drug resistance and tumor progression. Therefore, development of new therapeutic strategies for bladder carcinoma may lie in understanding the roles that these signaling pathways play in tumor progression.
CXCL5 (C-X-C motif chemokine ligand 5), also named epithelial-neutrophil activating peptide-78 (ENA-78), is a small (8-14 kDa) protein that is a member of the CXC chemokine family. It is an inflammatory and angiogenic chemokine that binds to its cell-surface receptor CXCR2 to execute its roles in angiogenesis, immune response, tumor progression and invasion by activating the PI3K/AKT pathway-induced up regulation of matrix metalloproteinase. Numerous reports have indicated that CXCL5 plays vital roles in cancer progression in various neoplasms; abnormal expression of CXCL5 has been identified in many tumors. It is overexpressed in gastric cancer, prostate cancer, endometrial cancer, hepatocellular carcinoma and pancreatic cancer. Increased expression of CXCL5 is associated with advanced tumor stages, local invasion, metastatic potential and cancer-related inflammation, which is involved in many aspects of malignancy in cancer biology.
Though studying the Immunohistochemical expression of CXCL5 in bladder carcinoma to assess its role in tumor cell proliferation, migration and spread is debatable. Recent studies have revealed that CXCL5 could serve as a potential prognostic biomarker for patients with bladder carcinoma. However, its prognostic value is still controversial owing to the fact that most studies reported so far are limited in discrete outcome and sample size. Therefore, Knowledge about the role of CXCL5 in UC progression, invasion and metastasis, and its prognostic significance needs further elucidation.
Aim of This Work:
The aim of this study is to evaluate the expression of CXCL5 in non-invasive and invasive urothelial carcinoma of the urinary bladder and to correlate its expression to different studied histopathological parameters to evaluate its potential prognostic value.

primary_outcome.measure: evaluate the expression of CXCL5 in non-invasive and invasive urothelial carcinoma of the urinary bladder and to correlate its expression to different studied histopathological parameters to evaluate its potential prognostic value

study_pop.textblock: Fifty specimens of primary invasive and non-invasive urothelial bladder carcinomas obtained from patients who underwent cystoscopic resection and/or radical cystectomy in Urology Department of Sohag Faculty of Medicine, according to local Ethical Committee regulations, to be examined in the Pathology Laboratory of the same Faculty.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:Patients with primary invasive and non-invasive urinary bladder urothelial carcinomas.
-
Exclusion Criteria:
- - Patients received pre-operative chemotherapy or radiotherapy.
- Patients with insufficient clinical data.
- Specimens with extensive necrosis
- Tiny specimens which are insufficient for accurate diagnosis.

responsible_party.investigator_title: Lecturer at Pathology Department, Faculty of Medicine, Sohag University
